newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Central America seeks diverse S. Korea investments.
newsitem.headline: Central America seeks diverse S. Korea investments.

text.p: The economy ministers of Central America met with their South Korean counterpart Wednesday and asked him to promote more diverse investments in the region, a government official said.

"We want to study the diversification of Korean investment in the region, especially towards areas other than (textile assembly) and towards activities that will leave more profit in the region," Guatemala's Economy Minister Juan Mauricio Wurmser told a news conference.
South Korea's Economy Minister Jaeyoon Park was in Guatemala as part of the delegation of President Kim Young-sam, the first South Korean head of state to visit the region.
Most Asian businesses in impoverished Central America are so-called maquiladoras, or assembly plants that take advantage of cheap labor to produce apparel and other goods easily made by hand.
The Korean delegation leaves Guatemala Thursday to visit Argentina, Brasil, Chile and Peru.
Park and the ministers of Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador discussed trade deficits, Korean investments and Central American exports.
Park said no South Korean investors, especially from large industrial conglomerates such as Samsung, Daewoo and Hyundai, had come to Central America with the delegation.
"I am supposed to relate information to them at my return," he said.
Wurmser said the ministers spoke of establishing commercial missions across the Pacific to stimulate the interest of mid- and large-sized Korean investors.
"If only Hyundai would come here to invest," Wurmser told reporters.
According to Wurmser, Central America's trade deficit with Korea was $110 million in 1995, with Central American countries exporting only $17 million worth of goods to Korea.
